reviews.review_msg: Uninspiring class. Professor does not put any effort.

One of the worst profs I have had in my entire undergrad. He initially seems nice and laidback and seems like a decent guy outside the class but as a professor, he is so disorganized and inconsistent with his feedback and grading that it is honestly embarrassing. The course itself has interesting topics but it needs a competent professor. Avoid.

Aneesh is kind and an eloquent speaker. He would bring in remote guest speakers in the industry - which was a good opportunity for networking and learning about branding. However, when it came to teaching, he often ran out of time in class and he seemed scattered all over the place. He is a tough marker and unclear with his grading assessments.

He has a rubric for marking but he is unclear about what he wants and never gives feedback on assignments so you don't know how to improve. His syllabus does not break down how anything is graded (participation is 30% but peer review marks factor into that which was never mentioned). He is quite disorganized and his lectures feel all over the place

Poorly structured course with no clear framework or relevant textbook. Exams were long and confusing, with vague questions and strict grading. Final project felt unrealistic and unhelpful, ironically on a product we critiqued as a failure in another course. Limited feedback or chance to improve. Regret taking this course for my last term at SFU.
Valuable industry experience, knowledgeable, approachable and well articulated. Andrew is everything you look for in a prof.

Andrew did a great job teaching this course. I learned a lot of information that is applicable not only to this class, but to real world employment situations as well. He uses a lot of examples regarding his own career to supplement the course material and it is generally beneficial. Very clear grading criteria and tests were completely fair.
